#1

I just learned that Heritage Guitar company is owned by a Chinese conglomerate, which means that former Gibson factory is now under Chinese ownership.

I was under the impression that Heritage was privately owned, well it turns out they were sold to Asians few years back. I am sure there are benefits of being part of a larger corporate entity (such as access to capital for expansion and renovations), however there are drawback as well.

It makes me feel sad that former American iconic factory is now in foreign hands, meaning foreign owners call the shuts at Heritage and can do the same to Heritage as they did to Hamer guitars (stopped US production and moved manufacturing to Asia).

We often talk about Gibson owning factories in China, well now we have Chinese owning Gibson factory in the US.

It also makes you think whether this an indication of what the future will be for Gibson and Fender...

If they were in the hole, and the only way to survive was to be bought out, I can't begrudge them selling to the highest bidder, or the best fit for their business. Beggars can't be choosers after all.

Who cares about the nationality of the owner? Surely their character matters more? Has anything changed with the guitars themselves? It doesn't seem like it but I'd like to be corrected if someone has information contrary to that.

Considering most of you guys know nothing else except where the owner is from, and are basing your entire judgement on "the owner is Chinese", and then thinking that's immediately a negative... Well that speaks for itself about the kind of outlook you have, as wrong and myopic as it is.

And I did some research.

Heritage is owned by Bandlab, they're Singaporean, not Chinese.
